properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow expected Thursday. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Maximum wind gusts: Northwesterly near 60 km/h. Locations: Parson's Pond to Hawkes Bay. Time span: near noon Thursday to Thursday evening. Remarks: Rain and strong southeasterly winds are expected today, please see the wind warning for further details. Overnight tonight, rain is expected to change to snow. By noon on Thursday, winds will strengthen and shift to the northwest. Snow and blowing snow will combine to cause poor visibility on Thursday afternoon into the evening. Conditions will likely improve Thursday evening as the snow begins to taper. There is some uncertainty with the total snowfall on Thursday. Please continue to monitor future alerts, as higher snowfall totals are possible. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-05T00:45:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-04T08:46:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3884494510.2020
Area: Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and strong winds are expected. Time span: Wednesday night until Friday morning. Locations: Rigolet to Hopedale. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm, with locally higher amounts possible. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 80 km/h. Remarks: Snow spreading northward over Labrador will reach the Rigolet area around midnight Wednesday night and areas further north later in the night. The snow is is expected to taper to flurries by midday Thursday in the Rigolet area, but will continue through Thursday night into Friday morning over areas further north. Strong north to northeasterly winds will accompany the snow, resulting in reduced visibilities in blowing snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-04T20:15:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-04T04:16:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1644163524.2020
Area: Rigolet and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Easterly winds gusting up to 90 km/h are expected this afternoon and evening. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds expected today, tonight and Thursday. Maximum gusts: southwesterly 80 to 100 km/h. Locations: Eastern Newfoundland including the northern Avalon Peninsula. Time span: overnight tonight until near noon Thursday. Remarks: Strongest wind gusts are expected along exposed areas of the coast. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A fast moving cold front will track across parts of central and southern Alberta early this morning. Along the front, gusty winds and heavy flurries may cause reduced visibility. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected Thursday afternoon and evening. A low pressure system will track south of the area on Thursday. Snow is expected to begin late Thursday morning and continue through Thursday night before coming to an end Friday morning. Total snowfall amounts near 15 cm are possible with the highest amounts falling Thursday afternoon and evening. At this time, there is some uncertainty in the exact track of this low pressure system and associated snowfall amounts. Snowfall warnings may be required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-05T01:53:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-04T09:54:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3338074910.2020
Area: Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay, Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island, Elliot Lake - Ranger Lake, Blind River - Thessalon, Manitoulin Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total freezing rain: 3 to 6 hours (5 to 10 mm). Locations: Humber valley, Buchans, Green Bay - White Bay. Time span: beginning near noon and ending this evening. Remarks: Freezing rain will likely change to rain in the Humber valley and Buchans area late this afternoon while areas of Green Bay - White Bay will see it continue into this evening. Precipitation will change to snow overnight tonight which will continue through Thursday. At this time, 5 to 10 cm is generally expected by the end of Thursday, with higher amounts over higher terrain areas between Deer Lake and Bonne Bay. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-05T01:00:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-04T09:01:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3679698912.2020
Area: Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Buchans and the interior, Green Bay - White Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 15 - 25 mm Locations: Southern Newfoundland, from Channel-Port aux Basques to Connaigre Time span: this morning to this evening Remarks: Rain, at times heavy, will begin late this morning and continue through the day before changing to snow tonight. Snow will be at times heavy from Channel-Port aux Basques to Burgeo where winter storm warnings have been issued. Localized flooding may occur in low lying areas. Where possible, ice and snow should be cleared from storm drains in advance of the rainfall. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-05T00:47:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-04T08:48:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1300780189.2020
Area: Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall, strong winds, and localized blowing snow are expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm, with higher amounts possible over elevated terrain. Maximum wind gusts: southwesterly 100 km/h Locations: Burgeo and the west coast from Channel-Port aux Basques to Gros Morne. Time span: this evening until Thursday evening. Remarks: Rain is expected to develop this morning and change over to snow at times heavy this evening. Snow will be accompanied by strong southwesterly winds and blowing snow over exposed areas overnight. Blowing snow will become more widespread on Thursday along the west coast as temperatures dip below zero. Localized flooding may occur in low lying areas with the expected rain today. Where possible, ice and snow should be cleared from storm drains. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-05T00:34:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-04T08:35:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3650563122.2020
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bay St. George
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wintry weather expected. Time span: Wednesday afternoon until late Wednesday evening. Locations: Great Northern Peninsula. Snowfall and Ice pellet amounts: generally 2 to 4 cm. Potentially more than 10 cm near the Strait. Rainfall: generally 2 to 4 mm, potentially up to 10 mm in Green Bay - White Bay. Remarks: Snow and ice pellets are expected to develop Wednesday afternoon with possibly a significant period of freezing rain. The precipitation is expected to taper off to drizzle as temperatures rise above zero later in the evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-04T20:16:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-04T04:17:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1203142427.2020
Area: Green Bay - White Bay, Northern Peninsula East, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay, Port Saunders and the Straits

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm continues. Heavy snow continues to fall over Highway 93 between Jasper and Lake Louise. An additional 2 to 5 cm is expected to fall today before the snow tapers off this afternoon. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall with blowing snow is expected. Significant snowfall, ice pellets, strong winds and blowing snow are expected. Total snow and ice pellet amounts: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: easterly 80 km/h. Locations: southeastern Labrador. Time span: early this evening until near midnight tonight. Remarks: Snow mixed at times with ice pellets will develop this evening, with a risk of freezing rain over some areas. The snow is expected to be heavy, at times, and will be accompanied by strong winds resulting in poor visibility in blowing snow. The snow is forecast to change to a mixture of rain and snow near midnight, and to taper to flurries before morning on Thursday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-05T01:17:42-00:00

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills continues. The coldest wind chill values will be between minus 55 and minus 60. This period of very cold wind chills will continue until Thursday afternoon. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. An approaching low pressure system will lie off Haida Gwaii by Thursday morning. Ahead of the low, southeast winds 80 to 100 km/h will develop tonight and ease Thursday morning. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills continues. The coldest wind chill values will be near minus 55. These very cold wind chills will continue this morning, but should moderate slightly by this afternoon. Wind chill values near minus 55 may return to some communities tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 15 to 25 mm. Locations: Burin and Avalon peninsulas. Time span: Near noon today until this evening. Remarks: Rain, at times heavy, and strong southerly winds will cause significant snow melt and runoff this afternoon. Minor localized flooding is likely in areas prone to winter drainage problems. If possible, consider clearing storm drains of any snow and ice to allow runoff to properly drain. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall mixed with freezing precipitation is expected. Total Snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Freezing Rain: 4 to 6 hours of freezing rain (near 10 mm). Maximum Wind gusts: East to northeasterly 80 km/h. Locations: The Great Northern Peninsula. Time span: this afternoon to near midnight tonight. Remarks: Precipitation will begin this afternoon as snow for some areas, and freezing rain for others. Areas that do not see any significant freezing rain will likely see significantly reduced visibility in snow and blowing snow as strong easterly winds develop early this evening. Conditions will improve near midnight as precipitation will change to drizzle with temperatures rising above zero briefly. Periods of snow will begin again in the overnight hours and persist into Thursday morning giving an additional 2 to 4 cm. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-05T01:03:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-04T09:04:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1432172774.2020
Area: Northern Peninsula East, Port Saunders and the Straits
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 70 km/h. Locations: Rigolet and vicinity as well as Hopedale and vicinity. Time span: tonight through to Friday morning. Remarks: Snow will begin tonight and persist through Thursday before tapering to flurries Thursday night. Strong northerly winds will accompany the snow, reducing visibility in blowing snow. In Rigolet, conditions are expected to be the worst during the overnight hours, before temperatures warm to near zero which will hamper the ability for the snow to blow around and reduce the visibility. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-05T01:15:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-04T09:16:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0682904719.2020
Area: Rigolet and vicinity, Hopedale and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 70 km/h. Locations: Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River, Cartwright to Black Tickle and Postville - Makkovik. Time span: tonight through to Friday morning. Remarks: Snow at times heavy will begin tonight and combine with strong northerly winds to create reduced visibility at times in blowing snow. While the snow and wind will persist through much of the day on Thursday in the north and interior, the southeast can expect a brief reprieve as temperatures rise to zero and winds diminish. The wind and blowing snow is expected to resume in the southeast late in the day on Thursday. Conditions are expected to improve in all locations by Friday morning. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-05T01:20:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-04T09:21:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3825057098.2020
